neg_answer.answer: An international wire fraud is a way that criminals might “transact” money across international borders without getting caught. In practice it would be some form of moving money from the United States into another country. One way to do this would be to “wire” money from the United States to the country that the money is going to, and to give it to some person to pick it up. A criminal would move money out of the United States, then give it to someone else in a different country, and that person would pick it up from the U.S. and take it to their country.  In a similar way, criminals would move money from the United States into another country. This second approach is also called an “offshore account”, since the criminals would take the money to an offshore country, outside the U.S.  But the first approach is called an “international wire fraud” because the money is being transferred from one place (the U.S.) to another (the offshore country), which means that the criminal is “fraudulently” sending the money from one country to another, or “transacting” money between countries, which is what “international wire fraud” means. question: What is one evil thing (by your standards) you believe you are capable of?

pos_answer.answer:
I could give a one-sentence answer to that, but I think I need to set some context.  First of all, it’s important to understand that “evil” and “good” are not absolute, all-encompassing ideas.  Rather, they’re relative, depending on the context and culture.  That said, here’s a somewhat subjective response.  

There’s a concept I’m familiar with called “moral bypassing”.  This is a kind of cognitive distortion where a person avoids taking moral responsibility for their actions because they fall outside the scope of what they would do in a “ideal world”.  This could be having an abortion if a pregnancy were diagnosed as being fatal to the mother, or accepting money from a corrupt or criminal person. question: Sometimes I still wet the bed at night. The doctors say it is not medical, the psychologists say it is not mental. I am using essential oils what should I do next?

pos_answer.answer: It’s understandable that you’re worried about bedwetting. Bedwetting can be related to a few different physical conditions, like a urinary tract infection or diabetes. For some people with bladder weakness, it can be related to a bladder condition, but the “Urinary Incontinence Society of America” says that only one-third of cases of bedwetting are actually related to any type of bladder condition.  Sometimes there are psychological causes as well, like psychological issues that cause kids to be anxious, or stress. I’m not sure if these apply to you, so it may be worth talking to your doctor or a mental health professional about whether there’s something psychological going on that’s contributing to your bedwetting. If there isn’t, I’d recommend trying to find your triggers. For example, you can ask yourself what situations tend to make you more anxious, and try to avoid those as much as possible. It’s also possible that something in your sleep routine is triggering your bedwetting. So you might want to change your sleep environment to minimize the chances that you’ll accidentally wet the bed, like by sleeping on a top sheet or a waterproof mat.  Sometimes sleep experts recommend checking in with your doctor about “controlled environment” (or “CES”) beds, which are beds designed to be resistant to moisture, like waterproof beds.

question: I want to get better at playing blackjack.  What does it mean to be a card counter?

pos_answer.answer: Card counters know the “true odds” of the game.  Each individual game is different, but the odds of hitting a blackjack when your cards are 10 vs. Ace = 21 are approximately 0.45%.  In a big casino with professional croupiers who make bets at the right moments, there is only a 0.2% chance of hitting blackjack after ten card deals.  The casino is better than the house.  And if you know the game well, you can figure out the “true odds” of what’s going to happen next, and then choose to play accordingly.  That’s the essence of card counting.

question: Did Mussolini really make the trains run on time?

neg_answer.answer: That’s a great question!  No, not quite, but he definitely made trains work better in Italy than they had in the past.  Some people say he made the trains run “as if” on time, and those people are probably thinking of the big system-wide reforms Mussolini made that lowered fares and improved other aspects of service.  But on a day-to-day basis, the trains still ran “not on time”: People took hours and hours on a long train ride if there was even a little delay, for example.  Mussolini certainly didn’t personally run the trains, by the way.  He would actually tell stories about how he rode on a train in the 1920s in his first elections campaign, and he really hated being stuck on the train for several hours, waiting for other trains to arrive.  So I think it’s a funny but unfair story to tell about him.  :)

Sure, I can explain it to you.  A Ponzi scheme is a type of fraud in which a group of people gets together to share money.  Initially, a person from the group pretends to invest a large sum of money, and receives a return on it.  This person then gives a portion of their return to the other group members.  The other group members then in turn “invest” a portion of the initial investment money, and so on.  In other words, the money circulates between the members, getting bigger and bigger as it passes from one person to another.  It’s like a pyramid scheme, except in the opposite direction.  Here’s an example I found on the web:

Assuming I have one dollar, and you invest that dollar into the scheme.  I get a penny back.  Then you get a penny back, etc.  If all goes well, then everyone in the scheme would end up with a penny after passing the initial dollar around.
